ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REPLACEMENT OF NTUC SECRETARY-GENERAL
(Request for Statement)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Prime Minister if he will make a statement on the reasons for his dismissal of the former Secretary-General of the National Trades Union Congress and his replacement by another Minister.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have not dismissed the former Secretary-General of the NTUC. Members of the Central Committee of the NTUC had written to me expressing their concern at their diminished sense of participation in decision-making. Later, at a meeting with me, members of the Central Committee stated their preference for Mr Ong Teng Cheong as Secretary-General.

    Subsequent developments have been set out in two exchanges of letters between Mr Lim Chee Onn and me.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Prime Minister. The Constitution of the NTUC provides for the Central Council to remove its Secretary-General. Why was it not possible for the Central Council to act within the Constitution rather than resort to you?

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know if the Member for Anson is the legal adviser to the NTUC. But no doubt he

Column: 10

ought to proffer his gratuitous advice to them. They did not ask him to interpret their Constitution for them. They came to see me because they felt that they would meet with someone who had an understanding of their problems, with someone who, apart from the constitutional relationships, would have their wider interests at stake and who, regardless of the constitutional position, would strive to bring about a situation in which the higher interests of the NTUC were advanced.

    I have not the slightest doubt that the Constitution would have provided them with all the legal means to get rid of a Secretary-General they did not wish. But that would not have provided them with a Secretary-General that they would wish, if it was Mr Ong Teng Cheong.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know why it would not have provided them with a Secretary-General that they wished. They could have taken the necessary steps to have him elected.

     Mr Speaker: Can I have your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question is: Did the Prime Minister draw their attention to the Constitution and tell them that they were masters in their own house, that they should act within the powers given to them and not have the Prime Minister intervene in the affairs of the trade union movement?

     The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson is envious of the rather friendly and fraternal relationships which I happen to enjoy with the Central Committee of the NTUC. It goes back many years. I do not have to tell them what they need do or need not do, and if they wish to seek my help I proffer it. If they act on their own, so be it. The reason why things have worked out well in Singapore is that both they and I have the good sense to know, first, what is the legal position; second, what is the ideal position.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Another supplementary question for the Prime Minister, Mr Speaker, Sir. What does the Prime Minister think about one of his Ministers heading a Ministry and at the same time assuming the post of unofficial adviser or leader of a

Column: 11

trade union for workers of a statutory board under that very Ministry of which he is the head? Does he not think there is a conflict of loyalties there?

     The Prime Minister: I am a little confused. I thought we were talking about the Secretary-General of the NTUC. We now seem to have wandered into some by-way.

     Mr Speaker: I think you are going out of that question of yours, Mr Jeyaretnam. Can you ask a supplementary question based on your question, please?

     The Prime Minister: I do not want to prevent any discussion. I just want to obey Standing Orders.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the question that I want to ask, Mr Speaker, Sir? Is he not aware of the announcement that the former Minister for Communications and Labour was apparently also the adviser to the Port Workers Union, and led the workers in making representations to the Port of Singapore Authority?

     The Prime Minister: I am not aware of such a situation.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: It is in the papers.

     The Prime Minister: I do not take cognizance of the same items as the Member for Anson does. Therefore, I seek the relevance of this to the subject matter which is the basis of his question. I will meet the point.

UMAR PULAVAR TAMIL HIGH SCHOOL
(Position)


    2. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what is the position of the former Umar Pulavar Tamil High School at Maxwell Road.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    Umar Pulavar Tamil High School was closed at the end of 1982, and the

Column: 12

remaining 64 pupils and 15 staff were posted to other schools.

    With the closure of the school, the site and the buildings were returned to the Land Office in accordance with the lease agreement between the Land Office and the School Management Committee. The school's library collection has been transferred to the Tamil Language Centre, and its furniture and equipment have been distributed to other schools and charitable organizations.

    The School Management Committee requested through the Member for Chong Boon for the Tamil Language Centre at the former Beatty School to be renamed the Umar Pulavar Tamil Language Centre. The Ministry has agreed to this and the Centre has been so named since the beginning of this year.

STATUTORY BODIES AND GOVERNMENT-OWNED COMPANIES
(Contributions to Consolidated Fund)


    3. Dr Toh Chin Chye asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the contribution of statutory bodies and companies in which the Singapore government has equity to the Consolidated Fund in the form of (i) income tax, and (ii) dividends, for the fiscal year 1982; (b) what is the capital share of he government in these statutory bodies and companies as at the end of fiscal year 1982; and (c) what is the yield on capital for 1982 from dividends.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Sir, the Singapore Government has equity (as I think the term is commonly understood) in two statutory bodies, namely, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (TAS). These statutory bodies, like all other statutory boards, are exempted from payment of income tax under the Income Tax Act.

    The Government directly holds equity, through the Minister for Finance, a corporation sole which invests directly in five operating companies and in three holding companies: Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd (THL), Sheng-Li Holdings Pte Ltd (SLH), and MND Holdings Pte Ltd (MNDH). THL, SLH, MNDH and their companies together

Column: 13

made an income tax provision of $259 million for the year ended 31st December, 1982.

    For the fiscal year 1982, the MAS paid dividends totalling $600 million. TAS is expected to declare a dividend of $20 million for the six-month period ended 30th September, 1982, i.e. immediately prior to its merger with the Postal Services Department.

    The holding companies have not paid their dividend to the Government, as all their surpluses are held for reinvestment. The holding companies received dividends totalling $121 million from their operating companies for the 12-month period ended 31st December, 1982.

    As at the end of fiscal year 1982, the total equity capital of the Government in MAS and TAS was $392 million and that through the Minister for Finance and in the holding companies was $1,726 million. All these entities are wholly owned by Government.

    The annual yields on capital for 1982 from dividends were 10.3% for MAS, and 13.7% for TAS. The rate of dividend paid by MAS took into account not only Government's paid-up capital but also Government's cash balances in the current accounts with the Authority.

    The dividend yields for the three holding companies were nil, The yields for the operating companies were nil for 34 companies (including eight which have yet to commence operations), 1% to 10% for five companies, more than 10% but less than 20% for 10 companies, and at least 20% for nine companies.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye (Rochore): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am gratified that the companies which are owned by the Government, including the statutory bodies mentioned by the Minister for Finance, are not losing money and are not being subsidized.

    But may I inquire of the Minister for Finance whether he will in future include dividends from these companies in the Budget Statement so that we will be able to fathom out how the revenue which the Government collects comes from.

Column: 14

Secondly, may I inquire of the Minister whether it is the policy of the Government to have Government companies muscling into the private sector at all?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: I did not get the last part of the question.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Put in simple words, Sir, is it the policy of the Government to allow companies owned by the Government crowding out private companies?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I must inform the Member for Rochore that the companies are run on the basis of private sector companies, i.e. their budgets are drawn up by their boards of directors. I do not know to what extent their budgets follow Government budgets but they are certainly not regulated in the sense that Government budgets are rigidly enforced. At the end of the financial year when the results become apparent, it is only the results, the balance sheet and profit and loss statements, that are made public by these companies, and I think rightly so. The public is then able to judge whether the companies have performed profitably.

    As regards the last part of the question whether the private companies are being crowded out, if that is the case we would not have a vigorous private sector. I think their vigour can be seen by the Stock Exchange quotations every day, and while there are Government companies in the list of publicly listed companies, I do not think they are a majority in this Exchange.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has missed the point. If Government companies have the authority of Government behind them, therefore they have an advantage -

     Mr Speaker: Dr Toh, may I have your supplementary question?

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: May I ask the Minister for Finance, for example, whether INTRACO is a Government company and PIE is a Government company?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: INTRACO is a company in which the Government has some equity. I believe the proportion is somewhere around 20%. So in a sense it is not exactly a Government controlled company, although 20%, of course, is a fairly

Column: 15

considerable share. In the case of PIE, the answer is yes, it is a Government company.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye: Is the Minister for Finance aware that the PIE made history last year by flying in 1,500 breeding pigs by Jumbo jet? Will private farmers be allowed to do the same thing?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Perhaps the Member is referring to PIE's operations with respect to the Armed Forces. PIE provides some of the supplies for feeding our army and other armed forces. If the private sector is equally viable, equally able to supply foodstuffs, I see no reason why they should not also compete with the PIE. The PIE is treated, I think, like any other Government company. It is expected to operate in competition with the private sector.

AIR POLLUTION FROM PIG FARMS IN PUNGGOL
(Measures to reduce)


    4. Dr Lee Chiaw Meng asked the Minister for the Environment and Minister for Communications what action the Ministry of the Environment will take to reduce air pollution caused by the foul air from pig farms in Punggol.

     The Minister for the Environment and Minister for Communications (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, pig farming is by nature pollutive and will give rise to malodour. It is not practical to completely eliminate the odour nuisance. However, the nuisance can be minimized through better housekeeping at the farms and improved waste treatment and disposal methods.

    During the day, the odour is less noticeable because the malodour is dispersed and diluted with rising warm air. However, during the evening when the temperature of the air is cooler at the ground level, the malodour does not disperse easily and the smell nuisance becomes more noticeable. Farmers have, therefore, been advised not to wash or flush their pig pens towards the late afternoon to minimize the nuisance.

Column: 16



    To further reduce odour and pollution caused by pig farms, farmers in designated pig farming areas are also required to install waste treatment plants by 1984 to treat their waste properly. The larger farms in Punggol are taking action to implement this requirement.

    One alternative to eliminate the smell problem is to rear pigs in completely enclosed buildings which, in our local weather conditions, would be uneconomic and impractical.

    It must be stressed that so long as we want to maintain a flourishing pig industry in Singapore, we would also have to accept some level of smell nuisance from pig farms. It is a price we pay for having pig farms in Singapore.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, does not the Hon. Minister for the Environment and Minister for Communications as well as my good friend, the hon. Member for Tanah Merah, agree that this foul air from pig farms does not come from Punggol alone as there are pig farms located elsewhere?

     Mr Speaker: That is not a supplementary question at all. Mr Ho See Beng.

PRIORITY FOR HAWKER LICENCES FOR APPLICANTS COMPELLED
TO SURRENDER HDB SHOPHOUSE TENANCIES


    5. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for the Environment and Minister for Communications if he will consider granting priority for hawker licences to those applicants who have been compelled to give up their Housing and Development Board shophouses because they cannot afford to pay the increased rentals.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Teo Chong Tee) (for the Minister for the Environment and Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    My Ministry is not in a position to provide assistance to shopkeepers who could not pay their rentals to HDB. Markets or food centres are built primarily for the

Column: 17

resiting of street hawkers. There is already a shortage of stalls to cater for the remaining street hawkers, especially those selling cooked food and piece and sundry goods. It is, therefore, not possible to consider allocating hawker stalls to those shopkeepers who could not afford to pay the increased rentals. If they have the skills to take up hawking, they can always rent space in coffeeshops and other food establishments.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether his Hawkers Department has guidelines for those applicants who deserve priority or are given hawker licences if they are hardship cases.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, we do consider cases which are justified hardship cases.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION ACT/EMPLOYMENT ACT
(Raising of wage ceiling)


    6. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for Law and Minister for Labour whether he will review the present wage ceiling of $1,250 per month specified in the Workmen's Compensation Act and the Employment Act and consider raising it to a higher ceiling to take account of the current level of wages.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for Law and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    The present wage ceiling of $1,250 pm provided under the Workmen's Compensation Act was last revised in 1981 to bring it in line with the amount prescribed in Part IV of the Employment Act. The revision from $750 to $1,250 took into account wage increases during the period between 1971-1980. The need for another revision of the wage ceiling so close after the last one is, therefore, not justified. It is, however, the Ministry's intention to adjust the wage ceiling at regular intervals if the increase in the level of wages warrants it.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, what

Column: 18

percentage of the total workforce is presently earning salaries below $1,250 per month?

     Mr Eugene Yap: Sir, it would be about 87% to 88%.

FIRE AT NO. 130 ANSON ROAD


    7. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will say whether the Police or the Singapore Fire Service have discovered who or what was responsible for the fire that occurred at No. 130 Anson Road on 20th May, 1983.

They prescribe drugs and they decide when to discharge patients. Blumberg, in 1979, has estimated that physicians control 70% of total health spending. Thus, physicians' propensities to prescribe costly services are of particular interest from the point of view of total health care spending and medisave. I quote from page 173, paragraph 2 of THE HEALTH, ECONOMICS AND HEALTH ECONOMICS.

    "Inducing providers to curtail the rendering of those services which yield very low or no marginal health value may be a far more effective and acceptable way to limit spending than attempts to reduce the price or unit cost of services, or to make consumers pay a larger fraction of the price".

    Let me give you evidence of what I mean by low marginal health benefits. Hutter and his colleagues at the Massachusetts General Hospital, in 1973, reported a study of early hospital discharge from myocardial infarction, that is, heart attack. Uncomplicated patients were randomly assigned to either a 2 or 3-week hospital stay. During the 6-month follow-up period, there was no difference between the 2-week or 3-week patients in frequency of return to work, anxiety or depression, heart condition or survival. You must have heard of coronary artery bypass graft surgery now in vogue. Many top politicians in the United States have a bypass done for their ailing heart. By 1977, its annual volume exceeded 70,000 at a cost of roughly US$l billion. The Veterans' Administration started a randomized clinical trial in the early 1970s with more than 1,000 patients, roughly half of whom were treated medically, the other half with this operation. The results were published in 1977 by Murphy et al. Surgical treatment was found to prolong life for the 11% of patients having diseased left main coronary arteries. In the rest, there was no statistically significant difference in survival between the two treatment groups at follow-ups, 21 and 36 months after entry into the trial.

Some have argued that surgical technique has improved considerably since the trial was conducted, and that there are important quality-of-life benefits not measured by survival rates.     Nevertheless, there is no ground for us to be complacent in regard to water supply. Because we have limited land to set aside for water catchment, water is a very precious commodity in Singapore.     22. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, in view of the widespread use of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and the possible dangers associated with its use, what steps are being taken to protect the public to curb improper decanting by unscrupulous traders.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: I am grateful to the Member for Thomson for raising this question. I can assure him that my Ministry is as concerned as he is about the possible dangers that can arise from the use of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). LPG is a highly inflammable fuel and approximately 60 per cent of households in Singapore use it for their domestic cooking.

    There have been reports of unscrupulous operators decanting LPG from large industrial cylinders into small cylinders using improvised equipment without paying attention to safety. The danger arises when the valves of the cylinders are tampered with during the improper decanting. Gas leakages arising from tampered valves can cause serious accidents endangering not only the operators but also innocent consumers.

    My Ministry takes a serious view of these dangerous practices. We have consulted the oil companies and relevant Government bodies on ways to eradicate improper decanting of LPG and protect the safety of the public. My Ministry has decided that it is in the public's interest that the LPG trade be regulated through licensing of all suppliers and dealers of LPG in Singapore. The licensing will compel suppliers and dealers to run a clean and honest operation and comply with certain safety standards including the use of security-valve sealing. The requirements for suppliers and dealers to be licensed are set out below.

    My Ministry will be enacting a set of Regulations governing the sale of LPG in Singapore under the Restrictions on the Supply, Distribution and Use of Petroleum and Electricity Act, 1973. Anyone who contravenes the Regulations will face a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for a term of two years or both such fine and imprisonment.

    It is proposed to bring the Sale of LPG Regulations into effect on 5 September 1983. To avoid disruption to the trade and inconvenience to consumers, existing suppliers and dealers of LPG will be given a three-month grace period from 5 September 1983 to apply for their licences. The Domestic Trade Section of my Ministry will administer and enforce the Regulations.
